text: bottle into glass, reddish clear pour with sour malt aroma, taste is bitter light fruit, had this in a bottle into a glass at the DUB, ok stuff
"kinda hard for this style to win me over. i dug the sharp hops in this brew and the nice floral bitter bote, but the malt profile didnt fo it for me. average beer."

Transfer from BA review on 10-5-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance- The beer pours a nice deep amber color with a one finger just off white head. The head fades rather fast leaving only a thin film of foam on the top of the brew and almost no lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The smell is heaviest of a bready and caramel aroma. Mixed with these smells are some grainy aromas as well as a little bit of a lemon citrus smell.

 Taste  The taste begins with a grainy and toasted bready flavor mixed with a caramel sweetness. As the flavor advances a little bit of an herbal taste as well as some grassy flavors come to the tongue. The caramel fades during the coming of the grass and herb, but is replaced by a light dark fruit flavor. In the end, with a little bit of citrus and toasted nut coming to the tongue a nice toasted malty and sweeter flavor is left to linger on the tongue. 

 Mouthfeel  The body of the brew is on the medium to slightly creamier side with a carbonation level that is rather average. The feel is quite nice for the roasted and sweet flavors of the brew all while maintaining a great easy drinking feel.

 Overall  A rather pleasant and easy drinking amber ale.
Bottle. Hazy orange pour - a little darker than I was anticipating. Caramel and some earthy malts on the aroma. Getting some citrus sweetness on taste as well. Medium-light bodied.

Bottle. Earthy, grass aroma with light notes of caramel. Pours caramel colored with a thin white head and no lacing. Starts with earthy and grassy malt flavors with a light body. Finishes smooth with sweet caramel lingering on the palate after. All right, but nothing to make it standout.

12oz bottle - Free State wiliibecker glass - Total Wine in Bellevue - ~$1.50
Aroma is very clean with just a mild earthy and melanodin hints. Flavor has a mild generic hop bite to go along with the same mild earthy and melanodin hints. Tingly, mineral, finish with a mild hop presence. Really nice vienna, could drink this for a while.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
Enjoy by date of " 09/03/14" stamped in white along the left side. 
This was poured into a pilsener glass. 
There was a two and a half finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute leaving some light somewhat foamy lacing clinging to the glass. 
The smell has a large amount of roasted caramel flavors presenting themselves in front of a toffee to nutty sort of flavoring. Light grassy/earthy bitter hops lightly dosed. 
The taste was mainly sweet and malty bringing back the nuttiness and the roasty caramel flavors. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionability about it. The aftertaste was semi - dry with a long drying finish. 
Overall, LTD series by Full Sail, solid Vienna Lager and now my interest is piqued in more of this series. Sure hope, this is just a precursor of whats yet to come...Full Sail send more LTD series beers.

2011 backlog. Pours clear dark amber with a 2 finger off white head. The nose is caramel, grain and fruity esters. The taste is the same for the most part with some faint roast in the finish. Medium bodied. Boring. 2.7

Bottle. Pours a very clear darker amber color with a moderate off-white head on it. Nose is slightly sweet and nutty, with just a bit of toast to it. Taste is much dryer than I expected, though there is a hint of sweetness on the back end. Slight bits of toast and nuts throughout.

A copper body with a fast fading white head. Aroma had mostly sweet caramel malts upfront. Some sense of toast malts and a nutty presence. Flavor was mostly sweet malts, there was a bit of spice from the hops. Thin mouth feel. Not a bad beer, but overall it was lacking in both flavor and aroma.

Bottle. 

A: Caramel color, thin creme head.

N: Malt, smoke, toffee, caramel, some pineapple, and earth.

T: Malty sweet, smoky, and a touch bitter.

M: Light body, a little resin.

O: a very nice beer. Good clean flavor. Gotta love a lager.
Aroma of sour dough and malt, copper coloured not much of a head taste of dough and malt with a creamy feel an a sour dough palate.
Pours a nice red color with white head. Caramel malt, bread, biscuit, and some roasted character on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more caramel maltiness.

Standard US longneck, perfunctory label. Packaging appearance offset by the bright, clear, bronze beer. Filmy ivory head with frogs eggs bubbles. Nice, dry nutty malt aroma. Toast, cereal, nutty malt flavor with light astringency and a little grass. Medium body, toasty-bitter finish. Not a complicated beer, but a refreshing one. Trader Joes, Tallahassee.
Fruity hops, deep amber malts, crisp finish. This is a really good interpretation of the styles. The lager balances out the taste of the traditional amber ale.

Orange amber pour, white head that dissipates to nothing. Simple, bready sweet malt nose. Flavor is same sweet bready malts with faint hop presence. Slightly stale tasting. Best by date is obscured (partially stamped) so Im assuming this is old... Hey full sail, if youre going to go through the trouble of using a best by stamp maybe make it at all legible.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber body under a small fizzy white head that faded to a thin ring pretty quickly. The nose is sweet vienna malt with a bit of light fruitiness and minimal to no hops. The flavor is fairly sweet with that little bit of fruitiness emerging on the back end thats a bit of a problem in a Vienna Lager. Minimal to no hops to balance out the sweetness from the malt. Not quite as clean as Id like. Light to medium bodied with a bit of cling to the finish and minimal soft carbonation. Meh, this is one I could pass on were I faced with the choice of having it again.

Bottle from Once Upon a Vine South on 05/03/2011. Dark brown body with a large frothy off-white head. Sweet caramel and toffee aroma. Sweet toasty, roasty and toffee aroma with some caramel. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.
Bottle. The look is very clear, copper colored, off white head. The smell is grainy, cereal, earthy, must, and toast. The taste is bread, slight sweetness, malt, fruit, and ok.
12oz bottle. Amber in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of leaves, malt, caramel, and bread dough. Taste is of dried leaves, dirt, caramel, and straw.

The beer pours very well with a nice reddish, brown hue to it. The head is full with a nice white creaminess to it and decent lacing. The smell has a nice scent of malt, mild caramel, a hint of coffee and a great mild smokiness to it. The taste is decent with the roasted malt flavors coming through instantly, which is then followed up with the light caramel flavor and a hint of coffee on the back end. The mouthfeel is nice with a lingering sweetness and mild carbonation that lasts on. Overall, this is a great beer from a brewer that I have never experienced before. If they do this well with most of their beers, then I would gladly pick them up in the future. As for this beer, it is part of their limited lager series and worth getting.

Full Sail LTD Series 05 has a medium, cream-colored head, a clear, deep amber appearance, with some bubble streams and practically no lacing left behind. The aroma is faint, but the taster can detect some bread crust, sweetness, barley malt, and just the slightest caramel. Taste is also low profile, but sweet, mild, brown bread crust, light bitterness, and malt are present. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Full Sail LTD Series 05 finishes wet, refreshing, easy drinking, and rather dull. Overall, it is good, but unexciting. RJT

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy/fizzy, off-white to light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark amber / medium brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted bread), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot, orange, herbs), with a light note of toffee.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively/fizzy carbonation.

Solid! The LTD series in general has seen significant improvements over the past couple years, and while Ive never had this particular one before, its probably never been better. Delightful toasty-cookie-toffee-ish malt character with soft citrusy hops. For the modest price, this is a very worthy quaffer.
Pours light brown with red highlights. Aroma is musty grain hay and herbs. Taste follows nose and is pretty sweet.

12 oz bottle dated 6/7/11 served in a pint glass.

Pours a clear red-brown (dark amber) color with a large head of light beige foam. Head dies down to a lasting thin coat and leaves a little lacing.

A - Not much aroma except for a not particularly attractive aroma of mixed grains.

T: near duplicate of Killians Red 

MF: Light/medium body; good medium carbonation

O - Sacrilegious to say this, perhaps, but this is very similar to, and certainly no better than, Killiians Red.
(from 2011 notes)

Draft at The Full Sail Pilsener Room in Portland, OR on 5 June 2013.
Clear amber colour with a white, dense head. Aroma of bitter hops and cereal malts. Initial hoppy bite with a dry toasty finish. Mouth feel was a little watery.

12 oz bottle- Pours dark rusty orange with a thin off white head that reduces to a collar. Aroma is some caramel, malt and some hops. The taste is very much like youd expect an amber to taste, caramel and toasted malt character, dry finish. This was okay, but not really my style.

Aroma very slight. Amber color with good head and moderate head retention. Taste of bitter hops. Moderate mouthfeel with good carbonation level. Overall a slightly heavy and bitter version. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A really nice doughy malt character in the mid-palate, modest hop bitterness to round out. Very drinkable. Not a world-beater but certainly a darn tasty thing.

12 oz bottle from a six pack bought at Super 1 in Rathdrum, ID. Pours mostly clear copper with a medium beige head with decent retention. Aroma is doughy, caramelly, citrus powder drink. Taste is sweet with earthy and caramel flavors. Mouthfeel is creamy, body medium to thin. Goes down really easy for this style; I dont usually care for it.

Poured a half finger of head on a clear, medium straw colored body.
It has a great aroma of grain with a bit of barnyard in the background.
The taste is wonderful. Full of grains with a nice malt background for a lager. Well balanced.
It is crisp with moderate carbonation.
A pretty good lager.

This rating is for the style.

Clear amber and nice maltiness with a subtle kiss of spicy hops. Lager lovers loves this.

Glad to see this on shelves again... I love the LTD beers.

A - Pours a clear amber/brown with a 1.5 finger off-white head the forms a solid ceiling. Leaves behind average lacing.

S - Toasted bread, woody yeast, faint earthy/floral hops, hint of alcohol.

T - Clean grain, sweet/toasty caramel malt, some mild raspberry around the edges. Hops come out toward the end and add a little spicy bitterness and stick on the tongue on the aftertaste.

M - Medium firm body, moderate carbonation.

Pretty flavorful Red Lager. This holds its own in the style. Good malt presence. This is a keeper.

Serving type: bottle

05-02-2011
Light bready aroma. Nice malt flavor: Bread crust, toasty, sweet, toffee/brown sugar.

Lovely dark amber color.  Smells of tart straw.  Tastes first of straight up malt then moves into rich spiced caramel bread with a tail of hops.  Light effervescence and medium mouthfeel.   Very sessionable and similar to full sails session fest.  Could hold up to even higher alcohol content.  Im thinking 7% or so.
Bottle at Columbia event. Pours a medium brown/amber color. Not much in the aroma, medium body, very sweet, finish really opens up, again, drinkable. Excellent.
UPDATED: APR 8, 2013 Dark amber pour from twelve oz bouteille. Breast nose with dark Amber Brown appearance. Malty syrupy.  bread finish. HeAvy for a v but good
Bottle pours a golden/amber with a thin off white head. Scent is toffee and bread. Taste is caramel with a roasted bitter finish.

May 16th, 2012 - A good amber is an amber that shines in a dull, brown and monotonous crowd. The amber is the safe style and the go-to 6-pack that lets a party hosted appeal just a little bit to all palates, rather than exceeding expectations for just a few drinkers. But Full Sails LTD Series Lager Recipe Number 5 is a cut above the mundane ambers that crowd the refrigerated section of my local grocery stores. Its an experimental recipe - whatever tinkering they conducted yielded a wonderful new take on the traditional amber; its a beer that engages the palate, rather than just slaking some vague thirst for beer. Dark chocolate brown in color, the depth and murkiness suggests that this brew might be thick with something - flavor, palate, gravity, its as yet unknown. Exploring the aroma, I find brown sugar and a heavy malta aroma, with the scent of fresh grass and sod. A dribble of honey appears in the aroma too, suggesting this is going to be a very sweet beer on the tongue. My suspicious are confirmed on the first sip. Lots of that rich maltiness comes to play on the palate, complemented by a mound of brown sugar, a breakfast oatmeal sweetness, a ribbon of caramel, and some glazed peaches and apricots., I overuse this word, but it fits so well here: toothsome. This is a sweet, delicious deep beer that has considerably improved the reputation and lot of ambers everywhere.

Clear amber with brown overtones and a creamy off white head. Hardly any distinct aroma - perhaps a little graininess. Flavor is nutty with a little marzipan and caramel. Hopped just enough to keep the finish relatively dry. Nice beer but not great.

Bottle. Poured clear dark golden color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted and produced good to good lacing. Moderate balance aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation. Moderate balanced flavor with medium balanced finish of moderate duration. The beer goes well with spicy soup.

12oz bottle from Gails Hops and Grapes in Hickory.  Brown-red pour with thin off-white.  Aroma is sweet caramel and bread.  Tastes are sugary malt, nuts, caramel, bread.  Sweet candied sugar dominates.  Not horrible, but not so great.
Botella, thanks yespr. Deep dark golden colour. Pleasant fruity herbal sweet aroma. Flavour: fruity hops, caramel, something herbal and malty. Nice... Vienna..?? quite different.

I always find Full Sail to be a good value even if they arent the best in their style. I think Ive probably had three sixers if this already since its only $6. Amber in colo of course with a smell like lager, sort of earthy too. Taste is decent, a little bready and easily distinguished as a Full Sail beer, maybe its the malt? Overall, an easy sipper and a good value.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-21-2011 00:36:08

Bottle at yespr. 
Clear orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, hops, grass and tea.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, grass and hops.
Hoppy finish.

clear dark orange, smooth white head.
mild aroma, herbal, spicy. flavor is malty, toffee, very slightly dark fruity.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Clear amber with an off-white head. Biscuity  sweet malt aroma. Medium body, rather sweet burned caramel aroma with a slight vanilla twist. Asolutely no bitterness. Totally like a well made, clean Amber Ale. 071112

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off white head. Aroma is fruity, toffee malty to light breadish. Bitter, toffee malty and light caramelish. Bitter and roasted malty finish.

Pours a dark amber-orange color with a small head that lingers a bit.  Malty aroma of bread, caramel, and yeast.  Taste is rich caramel malt, thick bread, and light toast.  Incredibly thick body and chewy mouthfeel for an amber lager, wow.  Best vienna Ive had.  Its more like bock really.  Well made lager.

Amber pour with an off-white head. Nice biscuit malt aroma, a touch of toast, and lots of bread sweetness. A bit of fruity esters, some mild floral hops, and a slight banana note. The flavor is lightly tart and metallic. A bit of toast, lots of biscuit, some bread, yeast, and fruit esters. Mild yeast flavor and a hint of grass on the finish.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear dark brownish-red with a one finger tan head that fades rather quickly leaving very little in the way of lacing.

Aroma of toffee and caramel along with noble hops. There is also some toast and nuttiness.

Flavor has caramel and nuts up front nicely complimented by spicy hops. Toffee and caramel in the background along with a little bit of toast. Moderate bitterness with a little bit of a creamy mouthfeel. Clean finish with just the smallest amount of stickyness.

Overall, a tasty lager but not one that really stands out from the pack. Really reminded me of SA Boston Lager. I would pick it up again if I saw it.

12oz bottle from my local Kroger. Bottled 8/18/12. Toasty caramel malts. Clear lighter brown color. Some bubbles on the side of the glass. Little greyish head. Moderate, soft carbonation, light dry texture. Sweet taste. Hint of honey. Decent amber lager, but doesnt really do anything for me. Pretty much what I expected

pours a clear caramel brown with a small dirty-white head.

smell is of caramel, malt, a hint of lemon, and pepper.

taste is creamy, caramel, some roasted malt, and a few hops.  ends slightly bitter.

Pours dark amber with a nice tan head.
Scent is bready, sweet malt.
Taste is slightly nutty, richly malted, biscuit, caramel.
Very flavourful and easy drinking.
Pretty good.
Bottle from Trader Joes. Slightly sweet malty nose. Sweet and roasty with a bit of chocolate. A little thin. Almost a smokey finish. Pretty tasty.

~Toasty bready malt aroma with sulfur quality. Biscuity. Light spicy hops.
~Pours clear copper color with small off white head.
~Bready biscuity malt flavor, slightly sweet with light spicy hops or balance.
~Medium bodied, med CO2, enjoyable sweet bready finish.
~Probably best Vienna I ever had, but I havent had that many. Enjoyable beer. Could drink a few of these.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, did not know it was a vienna style...dark reddish brown pour with thin white head, aroma has notes of dark roasted nuts, some hints of caramel, toffee, touch of biscuit, earthy notes, slight crisp and grassy hops, hints of earthy grain and husky notes.  Taste is sweet caramel, toffee, hints of earthy grain, nice snappy grass and spicy hops, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Hood River, Or - on tap at the brewpub after the excellent tour. Dark amber pour, off-white head, thick lacing.  Worty aroma with some fruity accents. Flavor has a hint of caramel, some bubble gum, some nutty notes. Thick enough mouthfeel.
This beer is crazy good. I havent enjoyed the last couple of editions of the ltd but this is exceptional. The malts are smooth and the hops are mild and crisp. So good.

The aroma is not very strong it is malty with a little roasted scent. Pours brown with frothy tan head that diminishes quickly and lots of carbonation. Taste is a weird vegetable flavor up front and then goes into a malty coffee yeasty flavor. Not my favorite. Im not sure why I keep buying these full sail ltd series.
Easily one of the lamest attempts at this style that I have had in a while. This is as about as close to Vienna as Shiner Bock is to Bock.
12oz bottle 7/25/12 Tulip¨Pours a clear medium amber witha small off white head. Aroma of roasted malt and cardboard. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew is bot too shabby. Nice job.
Bottle: beautiful dark amber color, with a small off white head.  Sweet, malty aromas help the well rounded flavor.  Its got a great body and finishes nice and clean.

On tap at Full Sail Hood River. Colour... Truly amber with a slight garnet hue and no head. Nose... Butterscotch candies and Malt-o-Meal with brown sugar. Palate... Light CO2, followed by a nearly candy like malt character and slight spent grain flavour that also has a bit of a tang to it. Finish is lightly sweet.

Definitely pours darker than the image shown on ratebeer however it is only by a little.  Pours light-amber bordering on dark golden with amber highlights, decent white head, and clear as a filter.  Head wafts of lager-like esters, sweet malt and slightly floral.  Tastes right on for an amber lager, malty sweet but not heavy bodied.  A decent amount of smooth bittering rounds out the palate.  Hops are definitely of the noble variety with no ctirus or distinctly american hop characteristics present.  Medium-light bodied with decent carbonation.  Overall, a malty vienna lager that has more malt sweetness and a touch more bitterness than most amber lagers that arent Oktoberfest style.
Out of the bottle. Pours a brilliant caramel color with a white head. Smell is mild and malty. Taste is smooth and sweet. The sweetness lingers and provides a full mouth feel. Very good.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours amber with a nice biege head.  Aroma of malt and caramel.  Taste is malt, caramel, a bit of citrus, and a bit of hops.  Easy to drink.

Not sure what the deal with Full Sail is.  They are committed to saving money on hops and using lager yeast.  Mine is much darker than the glamor shot in the description (and crap head).  A lot of malt in this, poorly fermented.  Much more of a beer than expected, but not a good beverage.

Thanks to Cavie for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a yellow-orange color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the grain and grass, with not too much else going on. The flavor is similar. The toffee and grain notes really stand out, with some grass from the hops thrown in. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Interesting beer...aromatic, full bodied and hoppy, yet it looks like an amber.  A note of caramel, but hoppy.  I think I prefered the LTD. 04, but this is a good quaff.
Biscuity aroma. Lemony citrus initial taste with a bready malt backbone. Nothing offensive, simple but bold flavor. Lingers on the palate.
Delicious limited edition lager, smooth with a great taste. Light enough to drink day or night, perfect summer lager.
bottle, clear amber color with thin foam, malty nuts aroma with nice caramel and honey flavors, an underated series
Its a fairly normal beer. Nothing offensive, easy to drink, safe alternative to the standard Lagers (Miller, Coors, Bud, etc.)

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2012 Aroma is rich caramel malt, some biscuit. Appearance is dark copper, clear, small tan head. Taste is rich malt forward. Fair amount of biscuit and bread as well. Minerally water. Smooth bitterness lingers in the end. Palate is medium light and very crisp and bright. Overall a very nice beer. Nicely malt forward but still crisp and very drinkable.

Deep copper in color with a nice off white head. Clean lager yeast aroma with a mit of breadiness in the malt notes.  Full mouthed, almost chewably nice bready matliness.  Full flavored yet clean.  Pretty good.  Deep copper in color.

Vague nutty aroma, not strong. Clear chestnut, medium head.Fizzy. Sweet malt flavor, like cane sugar sweet. Not a lot of character or intensity, perhaps some dried leaves. Strange sweetness. I dig the revolving lager concept, but not this edition.

Deep copper and light brown coloured body with a nice copper glow and a thick, three centimetre tall light brown head - nice looking, especially for a lager (given, its a vienna). Aroma of funky corn and wheat with a pungent sour milk and lactic smell that shows a bit of sugars and way too many odd scents. Light-bodied; Sharp metallic note with a lot of nuts and earth noticeable, showing off a little caramelised sweetness at the end and a bitter nutty flavour at the end, not great. Aftertaste is potent and not in a good way - too many off flavours and not enough holding this together. Overall, not a good vienna or lager and sadly a bit disappointing, especially for the series and the style. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Alexandria, Virginia on 28-May-2012 for US$1.99 sampled at home in Washington on 01-June-2012.
Bottle.  Dark amber, tall foamy head, high carbonation.  Slight musty aroma, malty.  Lengthy finish.  Decent beer.

Clean copper amber pour with two fingers of foamy tan head.  Nose shows plenty of toasted/biscuity malt with a nice bready character.  Lightly dextrinous with a n herbal hop quality.  Medium bodied with a light carbonation.
Bottle.  Amber pour.  Aroma of caramel and toasted malts.  Taste is a nice toasty and creamy flavor.  Nicely made.  Lower carbonation.  Smooth palate  Easy drinking.

Location/Date:Bottle on May 22nd, 2012.
Appearance: Dark copper cloud.  

Aroma:Sweet, caramelly.  

Taste:Sweet up front, caramel, light bitterness at the end.   

Palate:Light medium body, a little bit oily/slick, faint carbonation. 
Summary: Tasty well made lager, could be a good session beer.
CBC 12oz bottle-pours amber with a tan head.  Aroma is light/medium malt-some caramel, citrus.  Taste is creamy is light/medium malt-some caramel, light fruit hops.  Easy.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber with a spotty white head. Aroma of bread, caramel and herbal tea. Flavor is bready malt, sweet caramel and a light hop bitterness. Medium body with soft carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. Nice beer for the style, rich and smooth.

Pretty deep reddish amber with a thick, steady, off white head.  Nose is malty, toasty, some caramel, pretty on point for the style.  Flavor is similar, light sweetness, malts, caramel, lightly earthy.  Tasted very fresh, thankfully.  Would drink again.  Maybe the best Ive had in this series.
Poured into a pint glass. Nice head with aromas of caramel, malts, and Brown sugar. Very sweet and a tad bitter. Very easy drinking. Average beer..

Pours a light copper color with barely any head. Aroma is a bit of biscuity malt with some strong yeast esters. Taste is smooth with a bit  of doughy caramel flavor with some earthiness to it. Crisp on the palate. Fairly solid beer but not anything special.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2013 Well, as with their Bohemian Pils (LTD 03), evidently this has also been retooled. This batch features very malt-rich, breadcrusty characters which hint at melanoidins and scream blackstrap molasses. Good depth to the malt as well, as its quite dextrinous in feel. Dextrins are dusty and help to absorb the residual sugars. Quite candyish, but has a crunchy dark malt character that teeters on coffee and helps to balance with stiff definition.   On the sweet side of the spectrum, but a well-integrated Saaz-like softness  cleans things up. The previous batch was extremely unclean and riddled  with horrid defects, but this is markedly improved. So glad that Full Sail is doing some reflecting  and making adjustments where deemed necessary.  Purty nice, especially for $6 a sixer. Rusty gold. Nicely sustained fluffy white head. Bumbling and congested aromas of spent tealeaves, wet paper, metal, tomato, plum skin, cherry cough syrup, dried leather. Some minor sulfur and hairspray fusels, as well. A displeasing twangy fruitiness precedes a vague medicinal sharpness upfront. Shades of breadcrust along with a nut-skin earthiness lend the faintest bit of crispness, though the limp pale malt overshadows any semblance of refinement with a lifelessness which brings to mind wet paper and Communion bread wafers. Malt is strikingly devoid of any dextrinous heft or definitionjust plain fuzzy, dull, seriously underattenuated and riddled with soupy caramel, as well. No scratchiness from the hops, and absolutely no dextrins to dust the palate and contrast worth the overpowering red licorice slickness and Red Delicious dullness. Quite vegetal, as well. Closes limp with a vapid continuation of wet paper pale malt and spent tealeaves from the excess caramel malt. A very sweet, estery and, frankly, foul lager. Now, I will gladly tolerate some esters in lager if the beer is cleanly fermented, i.e. has room for them.  Unfortunately, in this case, the beer is already sweet and overcrowded, and the esters only add to the muddled character. But thats only one of many the things amiss here. Very shabby and generic. (Prev. score of the 2012 batch: 4, 4, 5, 2 = 2.3
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 12 ounce bottle. Poured brown with a thin white head. Aromas of sulfur, toffee, and malts. Flavor of breads, malts, and some fruity notes. A nice easy drinking lager.
For a lager/amber i absolutely love this. This is one of those beers you need to keep in your fridge at all times, if only that were possible. Best of the LTD series yet
22 Feb 2012, bottle. nutty amber, clear, no bubbles. nut brown nose, soft yeastiness, some alcohol. med body and moderately fizzy. wet wheat bread flavor w/ a twinge of caramel. pretty nice.

12oz bottle from Premier Gourmet.  Pours a lovely clear copper with a lasting two-finger fluffy off-white head.  Smells a bit like a amber ale / nutbrown cross - herbal, light roast, dry, mild alcohol, a bit of metal.  Taste follows, more bitterness, no metal, the alcohol is there in the taste.  Light body, a touch watery and astringent, mildly carbonated, with a medium earthy bitter finish.  Not sure what this is, but it was well-made ... vienna?  sure, why not.

Bottle [12oz]. Pours a clear orange-amber with a small semi-lasting frothy white head. Aroma of caramel malt, nuts, some fruit and very light hops. Flavour of caramel malt, nuts, light hops and a light bitter finish. Average to medium bodied. Nothing wrong with this but its also nothing special, an O.K. beer.

-- Rated via Beer Buddy.
Look Full Sail Brewing.....you know how to brew amber. Stick with what you know. This is like their standard amber on roids! Just start brewing this only.
poured a deep amber with a cream head.  nose is sweet malts, bread, light fruits, and crisp.  slightly roasted malts, dough, faint hops in the back with a smooth finish.

Cloudy amber with a thin tan head.  Aroma is mildly noble with mild caramel and dough.  Taste of Munich malts, caramel, light spice and faint hops with a light bitter finish.  Smooth but the most flavorful.

$6 sixer from sunflower 2/27/11.

dirty ochre shade of amber with a small ow head. 

initial sulfur aroma followed by spicy hops, sweaty yeast, malt, faint citrus and caramel. 

the flavor is the same... spiciness stands out. medium body. crisp and easy drinking. nothing impressive but not bad either. 6/3/6/3/13

A tasty, full bodied & hearty Amber. Going into it you dont what to expect, but its carmel flavor mixes well with a nice malty feel. Full Sails Amber is still one of my favorite Ambers, but the LTD 05 (like an Imperial IPA), is a welcome alternative
(12oz bottle thanks to Cavie) clear amber with a lasting fine tan head. Nose of caramel, corn, adjunct and chlorine. Taste of umami, salty, watery, raw grain and an oily body.

Appearance: deep amber, ruby highlights, creamy off-white head, decent lacing.   Aroma:  toffee, roasted nuts, caramel, strong note of toast.   Taste: toast, caramel/toffee, but of roasted nuts and crackers, mellow earthy hops.   Finish: clean, toasty sweet, lightly bitter.   Notes: Probably one of the top lagers Ive ever had.  Flavorful, balanced and delicious.  Incredibly drinkable palate.  Came in a Summer Sampler from World Market.  Mustfindmore

I can see that it is going to be easy to get hooked on these limited editions from Full Sail!!  This brew poured up a dark crimson red-colored body with a light foamy head that quickly dissipated and left minimal lacing effects on the glass.  Aromas of caramel, roasted nuts, hops and malts.  Flavors of the same; very well-balanced with a crisp, clean, smooth finish.  Light bodied so this is a very easy-to-drink brew which makes for a great session beer.

(bottle 5/17/11). Clear amber color. Medium off white head. Light toast/malt and caramel aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Light lasting sweet finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel aroma. Fruity malty sweetish grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel finish.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a very nice and very deep amber color with a small off white cap.  The nose has a touch of caramel, lots of cracker notes, and a slight vegetal note.  A touch sour up front with lots of cracker notes from the malt.  Dry and a bit biscuity on the back end.  The mouthfeel seems about right but the flavor seems a touch off.  Not bad mind you, just not really, really great.  Still, its definitely sessionable.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA, opened 3/24/11. Pours a clear dark copper color with a thin head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of grainy malts with a toasty finish and some faint earthy hops. The taste is toffeeish malts, berry-like fruits, earthy hop finish. Medium bodied.

The aroma pretty good with caramel malt and citrus-floral hops. The appearance is light brown with an average head. The taste is like the aroma but has a touch of cardboard. The palate is average for the style. Overall a slightly better than average beer.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine - Pours a clear deep copper color with a half finger thick off white head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is toasted malt, grain, and light herbal hops.  Flavor is much of the same.  Light hop finish.  Medium body.  A good beer.

12oz bottle from State Line. Would that Id stopped through when some of the other entries from the series were on sale. Viennas never been a fave style, and there was nothing about this one to change my mind. Rusty pour, flat in color if not in body. Has the look of what one imagines Michelob Amber would be, but thats unfair projection I suppose. Still, hedonic ratings so fuck it. Nose was indistinct fruit and a hint of dry zest, with grain and malts underpinning. Body was medium, with carbonation fading a bit too quickly. Flavors are a bit too sweet for me, with caramel a bit too dominant along with toasted grains. Maybe this is the mark FS sought to hit, but . . .

12oz bottle from BevMo.  Pours a very dark red-brown with head and lace. Nose is caramel and toffee, with a slight chocolate overtone. Flavor is rich and substantial, with the toffee carrying through and adding hints of green and black tea. Mouth feel is clean. Interesting, but not something Id drink every day.

12oz bottle from the state store 
Appearance: Pours crystal clear brownish amber with a medium sized off-white head and light lacing 
Aroma: Toffee and ripe fruit 
Taste: Toffee, sweet malts, ripe fruit and grainy 
Very nice and easy drinking

Pours a reddish brown, like a dark amber with a non-existent head and zero lace. The aroma was a bit vegetal at first, but fortunately that blew off pretty quickly. It turned into a pleasantly nutty aroma with hints of fresh grass, toast and pepper.

The flavor is pretty straightforward. A nice subtle hazelnut flavor with caramel and toast come through with a slight butterscotch linger. It almost has some märzen vibes going on, but not nearly as sweet. The spritzy mouthfeel gives this beer a crisp, clean finish.

This is definitely the best of the LTD series thus far, so I think they finally got their shit together.

Bottle. Pours with a clear brownish-orange body with a small, slightly off-white head that fades somewhat quickly. Aromas of nuts, lightly fruity (esters?), toasty and malt forward. Some cornbread. Lightly hoppy (herbal and grassy). Otherwise pretty clean. A bit sweet up front which slowly fades and finishes malty but dry. Toasty. The initial sweetness is a bit off putting. Crisp, no esters. Some minerality. Pretty clean. Dry, a bit thin, lively bubbles. No astringencies. Pretty decent overall, but nothing spectacular about this beer (for its style or in general).
Light amber color with a small off-white head. Toast flavour, a bit thin and lacking hops. Dont think it was very fresh though.

Pours deep amber into a Sam glass. Pancake batter head conglomerates as it recedes leaving spider lacing. Sweet hay aromas. Sharp with sweet caramel and vienna fingers front to back.  Lasting mild hop and vanilla finish.

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured amber with a white head.  aroma was caramel, sweet cereal, and slight citrus.  flavor is bready, caramel, and a slight hop bitter on the finish.  body is light with medium carbonation.

12oz twist-off bottle.  
Amber color, thin head.  Aromas of malts, new car, and autumn.  Sweet malt flavor, some autumn leaves.  Medium bitterness, lots of toast.  

5,3,7,3,12

Clear copper with a two-finger white head and ok lacing. Bready malt aroma with a touch of honey and light grain. Mildly sweet toast and caramel flavor, some light fruit like pear and red apple. Light to medium body, nice carbonation, and a rather uninspiring finish. Kind of bland.

Bottle poured a clear amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and toasted malt. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smoothj finish. Flavors of carmel and toasted malt with a smooth carmel finish.

Sampled on 6/22/201. This Vienna pours a medium copper amber color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel malt, toast, touch of fruit and some hops. A medium bodied Vienna. The malts are caramel and semi sweet. The hops are floral and grapefruity. Decent carbonation. A little drier than most Viennas, with a nice crisp finish. A surprisingly refreshing beer.  Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean, crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a hint of bitterness.
12 oz bottle pours a brown/amber color with a medium white head.  Aromas of malt, light caramal and light hop.  Light bodied with a sweet finish

Really love these LTD lagers! (except that 7% pilsner!) It pours a clear amber color with a decent off white head. The aroma is very toasted with some lager yeast esters, a touch of fruit, and great malty complexity. The flavor is again very toasty with some nice caramelized grains, noble hoppiness and a pleasing palate. Very nice job by Full Sail.

12 ounce bottle from the Utah State Store on Foothill. Pours a clear dark amber color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet caramel and dusty fruit. a smooth sweet flavor of caramel, some candied fruit, strawberries, very mellow and tasty. A nice brew.

12oz Bottle  Gravity Beer Market - Olympia, WA 
Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Sweet malt aroma with light hops backing.  Tasty malt flavor fruit esters with light hops.   Very tasty beer.  Full Sail is doing great beers here.
Clear amber color/ ivory head. Spicy caramel, mild floral aromas. Medium bodied. Decent lightly sweet spicy caramel, toffee flavors--
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: bottle.  what ever happened to #4?  disappointed i never got to try it considering the others have been so great.  big fan!  this one pours a clear brown/amber with a small, filmy, beige head.  aroma of sweet light floral, sugary nuts and caramel.  flavor is mostly nutty caramel malt and a hint of bittering hop.  light body and a clean, moderately dry finish.  another winner!

I thought I was looking for something pale, but I tried this instead.  What a nice surprise.  Firm malt body.  Grassy hop flavoring, mellowed by persistent carbonation.  Copper color matches the caramel aroma.  I cannot go back in history, but I now have a rival to Brooklyns interpretation of the Vienna style.
This must have been the best Vienna I have ever. It was nice and thick and had a good head on it. I expect nothing less from Full Sail.
Pours amber-orange whitish head. Aroma of fruits and malt, taste of sweet malt. Alright, nothing special.
Very nice overall beer. Citrus taste with medium head. Great summer beer. Enjoyed
Bottle from central market. Clear orange color with very little carbonation. Aroma is soured grain with cardboard and small malts. Flavor is dry and grainy with some bitter malts and salt.
Colur like a dark pee when you havent drank enough water. Malty sweet smell and taste. Funky finish.

Smells earthy and grainy.  Pours a rich clear brown with minimal head.  The malt really comes through in this one.  There is a crisp offset with the carbonation which has an underlying hop character.  Finish is crisp for such a malty beer.  Very nice. 6,5,8,5,16

Bottle at Texas Beerfest. Pours a clear amber with a medium frothy off white head that lasts awhile. The aroma is A sweet malt and floral. Thin mouthfeel with a light hop and citrus and smooth finish. Easy to drink a decent amber from Full Sail.

12 ounce bottle - $1.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a clear, reddish-amber body with two fingers worth of off-white foam.

Smell: Sweetish bready-scented pale malts, touches of caramel, lightly toasted nuts, and even a tiny hint of chocolate. Secondary scent of slight fruitiness.

Taste: Sweet, lightly nutty, lightly caramelized maltiness on the fore. Slightly fruity, hinting of candied berries. Mild, earthy-toned hops with a low bitterness barely making its presence known, keeping this a malt-forward brew. Very small hint of grains. Sweetish, malty finish.

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Ill be honest, its a skosh reminiscent of Magic Hats Vinyl, which is certainly fine, as I enjoyed that one as well. A mighty tasty malty red lager.

12oz bottle on Maxs special board this past weekend. Poured a clear, cream soda color. White head, not really any lacing to be spoken of. Slightly sweet, bready caramel malt, full bodied lager with a clean floral finish. Stop trying other beers after this one. Had about 6! Stocking my fridge now that its fresh...

(12oz bottle).  Pours clear amber with off-whtie head.  Moderate carbonation.  Aroma has florals, sweet caramel and fresh cut grass.  Taste is sweet with more caramel malts and some light bittering hops.  Medium bodied with a slick/oily texture.  Finish is smooth and slightly bitter.  A pretty good beer although its a little maltier than I prefer.  Still, I could drink a couple of these.  Nice job.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep amber woody copper with a thin lasting off white head- slight lace.  Aroma is nutty, toffee,  slight vege with green grassy hops, slight mint, then more slightly burnt or toasted malts, and some bread.  Flavor is toast, biscuit, slight burnt hint, grass, mineral, slight metallic off hoppy twang and a mild bitterness.  Gets a bit better as it warms up.  Ok.
Bottle from the Pioneer Majestic.  Light brown pour with a big off-white head.  Aroma is cardboard, musty, honey roasted airline peanuts, and grain.  Taste is toasty, butter, and bitter.

Pours a clear rusty orange with a moderate off-white head.  Aroma of butter (too much), dirt, toast, toffee, and green peppers.  Its kinda weird on the nose, but the flavor redeems itself with sweet caramel, toffee, earth, grass, and a slight peppery bitterness.  Finishes fairly clean with lingering earth and toffee flavors and most butter characteristics are outweighed by mild bitterness.  Still, I kinda wish it was drier given the sweet upfront flavor.  Almost light bodied, with a slight cloying aspect and chewiness.  Its got some good points and bad points.
(12oz bottle, courtesy of Cavie)  Pours a clear copper body with small white head.  Aroma of mustiness, toasted grain, earth, and nuts.  Flavor of grain, light citrus, caramel, and nuts.

malt-o-meal cereal aroma, with resiny hops, lemon. off white head doesnt hold long over clear reddish brown. a little under-carbonated (bottle.). I taste brown sugar, wheat bread, pine. tangy finish.

Light brown color.  Mild aroma of a lager with grain.  Flavor has more grain, lightly sweet and immediately recognizable as a Vienna.  A very drinkable, and well made lager.  These Full Sail lagers are awesome.

Bottle with a twist-off cap; "Lower the decibel" is printed underneath.  Pours clear reddish orange with a light beige head.  Aromas of light wheat, red berry, and caramel.  Bitter grass, lightly astringent, with some sweet malt in the finish.  Im not too crazy about this.  [690]

not a complex beer but i can drink the shit out of this. distributes in oklahoma, drank a lot while there, great price point. my fondness may be due to how well this goes down in hot temps and how hot it was there then. worth a try, especially when it is 90 out.
Amber pour.  Malty aroma, bitter hops.  Flavor is funky, stinky hops, earthy.   I really dont like this.
Shared with maniac at his place.  Clear amber pour with good light tan head.  Sweet and grainy nose.  Flavor is nothing special.  A little nutty and somewhat lightly spicy.  Didnt care for this one.

Amber, clear, good off-white, almost light brown head with good carbonation.  Taste is a good maltiness - sort of a slightly toasted bread with a touch of sweetness.  It very much reminds me of a thicker, fuller, Negra Modelo.  I really like this style of beer.
Bottle @ home. Dark orange/amber appearance with a foamy light brown head. Sweet caramel malty lager nose. Nutty, fairly light bodied, caramel malty, mildly hoppy flavor. Solid session beer.

Aroma is not strong but still malty and slightly fruity, just a little appealing. It pours a dark brownish amber with a thick, fluffy white head that leaves some decent lacing. Flavor is malty with a fruity undertone, mainly pear, and just a touch of hops. Texture is fairly smooth, just a little fizzy. Im not a big fan of lagers, but this is pretty good.
Clear chestnut color with a cm of white head.  Aroma is sweet, nutty...Vienna. Taste is the same, and well attenuated, with a fair amount of malt character.  $2/12oz

Full Sail - you never know what youre going to get with these guys.  This 12-ouncer came from my sister as a birthday gift as part of a mixed pack, and you know, it may be one of the better in the bunch.  Excellent clear dark reddish-amber in color with a small light khaki head and good lacing.  The aroma has nice caramel malts and mild toast.  Not too shabby, I must say.  The flavor is also very good.  A little grainy with caramel, toast and some earthy hops.  Just the right sweet/bitter balance.  Rather dry on the mouthfeel with medium body for the style.  Actually pretty solid.  Color me surprised.
Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Light toasty malty aroma. The flavor is clean and toasty with enough bitterness to balance. Good stuff.

[Bottle] Pours an orange color with a bit of haze to it. Large and lasting cap of foamy head. Aroma of caramel malts, sticky toffee and hints of smoke. Sweet rolls, mild spice, grassy hops and a light amount of smoke in the taste. Full in body and average carbonation levels. Toasted malty finish. I did enjoy this one quite a bit. Id but this again.

Bottle. Copper pour with a short, fizzy beige head. Caramel, spicy hops, dried fruit and dark bread in the nose. Taste is caramel, sweet malt, dark bread, grains, and light grassy notes. Bit of tea as well. Body is medium with a moderate carbonation. Finishes with more sweet malt, toasted dark bread, caramel, soft grass, and light spicy hops.

Bottle; poured a darker than expected orange/amber with a smallish off white head.  Aroma of citrus, fruit, caramel, orange, and bread.  Flavor tasted alot like a pale ale.  NW style hopping, but in balance.  Caramel and bread backbone.  Surprisingly tasty.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours dark amber with a nice big creamy offwhite head. Aroma of bread, toffee, hay, grassy hops. Taste is bready and caramel malts, light grassy and floral hops. Thin to medium body, lively coarbonation. Well made amber, but nothing special. 130411

Quite dark amber with a moderate, but quickly gone, whitish head that actually leaves a decent bit of lacing. Aroma is light, with some light malt, metallic, and slight spice and hop notes. Taste is slightly sweet malt with just a touch of hops at the finish. Medium body. Nothing special, it seems well made, its just a little plain.

12 oz bottle from 16 Tons. Surprisingly dark amber pour with a light bit of white head. Smells of grains, some bread, toffee, maybe a little nuttiness. Taste is sweet toffee, a little nutty, some bread and maybe light caramel. Probably my favorite of the LTD series so far, quite a surprisingly solid brew.
Pours a dark brown. Initial toasty flavor but still effervescent. Nice creamy head. Malt driven.
Sampled at a beer tasting, more comments to come as I organize my notes from the session.

Stupid beer! as i was taking a pic of this brew for the beer sites, my camera slipped, and i dropped the bitch and the screen busted, fuck! .. So this beer will will have to drown my sorrows .. . Pours a dark tan, with amazing head (which actually overflowed all over my side table) .. . aroma is not all that good, dusty and brown .. . Um... is it right to buy a Chrysler? .. . very smooth stuff, taste of light grain, caramel and nuts .. . A pretty nice brew, and quite a well made example of the style .. . Hello. Hello? Anybody there? Whats this, I hear the phone ring, and suddenly theres nothing. Im listening and theres no talking. Hello, mister, who are you? Why would they call if they dont want to talk to you?

Bottle. Pours a very dark red-brown with head and lace. Nose is caramel and toffee, with a slight chocolate overtone. Flavor is rich and substantial, with the toffee carrying through and adding hints of green and black tea. Mouthfeel is clean. Interesting, but not something Id drink every day.

12 ounce bottle purchased at Nugget Market in Woodland, CA.  The aroma on this is a bit metallic, with some floral hints.  Not overly pleasant to smell.  Transparent amber body with a creamy, off-white head and good lacing left behind.  Start with a little metallic flavor, before this becomes really toasted, and biscuity in the middle.  Lots of toast, light sweetness, and hints of caramel malt.  Finishes with slight floral notes and moderate sweetness.  Pretty clean and drinkable.  Something I could drink many of and enjoy.
Bottle. Copper-dark amber. Light head. Ligh malt scent with hints of cinamon spice. Light flavour of biscuit, cookies, ginger and cinamon. Close enough to style to pick out easily.

12oz bottle.  Small beige head atop crystal clear amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some earthy, nut, light orange.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange/earthy, caramel, some toffee, nut.  Light-medium body, some prickliness on the tongue.

Bottle. Pours clear copper with a tight white head that fades to collar and shows minimal lacing. Aroma is vegeteble and some malt. Taste is metallic vegetebles and finishes malty with some faint spice. Palate is fizzy and slick and dry.

Full Sail Brewing Company--Full Sail LTD Series--For Those Who Love Amber Ales, Heres A LIMITED EDITION LAGER So Crazy Good, You Might Convert To Lagerism--Recipe Number:  05--2011 12 oz. Bottle.  5.60% ABV.  28 IBUs.  (3.5 / 5.0)  No sediment.  Big foamy thin mild lace rapidly dissapating billowy white head.  Clear fizzy rich thin dark amber color.  Toasted biscuit caramel mild Saaz hop hint front.  Smooth toasted caramel mild sweet cocoa hint rustic bread crisp tasty malt body.  Slightly	cloying creamy chocolate hint mild hop clean crisp rich end.  Nice well made Amber Lager.  Tasty & smooth but not exceptional for a Full Sail.  Sampled 3/12/2011.  6-Pack purchased for $6.99 2 Fred Meyer--Ballard, Seattle on 3/12/2011.

Bottle. Rich amber beer with a cream colored head. Low malt and earthy aroma. Malt and light caramel flavor with mineral and earth. Medium bodied. Malt and mineral lingers with light caramel and spice.

Bottle stamped 052411-15:41-FL.  Deep and clean amber pour with a short burst of fizzy white head.  Rich, toasted malts on the nose with a slight pop up of yeast. Decent medium body. The taste is incredibly sweet reminiscent of Newcastle in the 1980s.  Overall an amber ale that seems right on.

Bottle: &nbsp Rich and deep vibrant amber, moderate foamy off-white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Malty up front, a little cereal and barnish/basement like mustiness. &nbsp A little sweet on the backside. &nbsp Somewhat mealy, but its minor. &nbsp Decent malt base, semi-sweet, enjoying it more than I thought I would based on the other LTD beers. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Does have a little mealiness that lingers. &nbsp Otherwise not bad, clean, and better than other LTD beers. &nbsp Still doesnt live up to Eliot Ness tho!

Somewhat mild aroma - toasty, caramel, light sweetness, light hop character. Amber pour, nice clarity, soft lace, good head retention. Flavor is lightly toasty and nutty with hints of caramel sweetness, grass, and light bitterness. Clean finish.

bottle.  Pours a clear golden brown color with average sized off white head.  Aroma of biscuit, hay.  Medium bodied, yet still very full feeling, smooth, creamy palate, perfect session lager feel.  Flavor has a distinct caramel presence, but it is very nicely done, not artificial or cloying, just tastes good.  Also plenty of toast, hay, and a crisp bite thanks to the hops, which impart a very subtle bitterness on the finish.  Simply a great lager, would be a go to beer for me.
Bottle:  Pours a clear orange with a thin white head, aroma has light grains and bread, light bodied with ample carbonation and a crisp ending, starts and ends lightly bitter.
12 oz bottle from Thriftway - Dark amber color.  Clear.  Not much character in the aroma.  Very smooth taste.  A little sweet and sour going on.  Nice one.

clear amber.  mostly clean pale and caramel malt nose; slightly metallic but sterile notes at times; mostly sweetened caramel and fusel vanilla touches otherwise.  light bodied, as expected, with chewy roundness mid-palate.  low hop bitterness but has medium to low malt astringency and harshness.  nutty, wet finish.  its okay fresh, but it seems like after only weeks in the bottle it will be done for.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2012 I found this to be a very nice beer all the way through. Easy drinking, light but flavorful. This was the only thing I enjoyed while watching Unlv lose last night. Would definitely buy again.

Bought again and had to lower the score a bit.

12 oz bottle from EZ. Poured a clear thinner bodied orange/amber with a smaller bubbly whitefish head. Aroma of amber grains, vegetables,  dry toffee, alcohol, crusty breads. Flavor is slightly more vegetative then the Aroma along with notes of slight citrusy chocolate.  Average at very best ........ahh who am I kidding this is below average and you will never see me buying this again.

Bottle: Pours a nice orange copper color with a nice respectable head. The nose is fluffy and toasty with some crisp clean malts, ample biscuit and a light sweet underlying caramel note. Chewy mouthfeel with a nice moderate body and a clean crisp maltiness and lingering hop note in the finish. Very well put together and a balanced tail. Refreshing and big bodied all in one.

Toasty nose, full and rich, nearly dusty.  Beautiful clear amber, small sustained white head.  Ah!  So toasty and consistent, little crackermeal, some white bread, ample weight on the palate.  Gets a touch metallic in the trailing finish, but 95% of the experience is joyous.
Bottle. Poured honey red with medium lasting white head. Aroma is biscuit and honey.  Medium balanced flavour. Lekker hop finish, but subdued.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle...  Poured amber with an off-white head.  Aroma had some floral grassy tones with a light, honey and cracker malted grain sweetness. Perfect carbonation for the mid ranged body. Mild sweetness, some good hop balance and loads of cracker and biscuit malts created a wonderfully balanced lager.

Okay, so number 4 was a slight misstep in an otherwise solid run - this one finds the brewers back in good form - nose is initially sweet, with notes of caramelized sugars - a bit of toasted grain and a touch of hops sit atop some fairly rich maltiness - full in the mouth - somewhat creamy texture - malty without being very sweet - just a hint of caramel up front and a bit of nutty character - a bit of toastiness arrives as the beer dries out, making way for some peppery hops on the tail end - a slight warming spiciness - simultaneously malty and slightly crisp - well done.

Sample poured at Wakefield Liquors - Wakefield, RI. Full Sail makes some solid beers and this is one of them. Big fresh grain and complex malt nose. Body was balanced, crisp, fresh, satisfying and had a delightful, but not overbearing Vienna fruit edge to it that added a fun touch too the beer without getting weird, as I think it does from brewers who arent good at lagers or who dont know how to malt the style. This works. Drinkable, seasonable (as opposed to being a sticky, somewhat boozy bock), and fresh.

The LTDs are coming faster now!
12 oz from a 6-pack . Winco  store S.Salem. $5.88
Handsome deep amber beer with a largish light tan head.
Very malty  aromas..toasted oat cereal comes to mind..a little nuttiness also.
Taste is  semi sweet toffee,again a dose of nutiness, Sweet honey finish..and perhaps the fainest hint of hop in the end.
Nice enough on the tongue..good feel to it.
Overall  a nice tasty lager

Bottle from the Co-Op in Davis, CA. Pours amber with a creamy/foamy beige head. Beautiful. Aroma is spice over mildly bready malt. Near full bodied; spritely carbonation. Theres a lot of malt here. Also a lot of spicey/herby hop. One of the tastier Viennas I can recall.

Appearance:  Pours a deep clear amber. It starts off with a dense fluffy homebrew like beige head. The head slowly subsides to a dense cap. Within the body, you can see visible rising carbonation.

Aroma: Sweet, bready malt, grassy herbal hops.

Taste: Mild sweet bready malt, grassy hops. Finishes with a touch of burnt caramel.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, creamy carbonation.

Overall: Above average, tasty, get it while its fresh.

Clear amber color with a small head. Aroma is caramel malts, cedar, and a hint of skunk. Flavor is moderately bitter, but kind of thin. A bit watery. Light body, thin and slightly fizzy texture. All around, this is a bit boring.
